Dear Ms. Williams-Burton:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 11/26/2018.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(b) A copy of the job description for the staff member's
current position.
Two out of 21 applicable employees hired within one year did not contain a copy of
their job description.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
One out of eight foster parent records reviewed did not have current certification in
first aid. The foster parent’s certification expired on 12/19/2017, whereas the annual
evaluation occurred on 09/11/2018.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 10/11/2017 RENEWAL INSPECTION
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (e), (g), (h), and (i) of this rule
annually for the duration of the child's placement.
One out of three borrowed home records reviewed did not contain an updated copy
of the parent-agency agreement. The last parent-agency agreement is noted to
have been signed on 01/20/2017.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
4

(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as
is indicated, based on the information received, but not later
than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
One out of three special evaluations reviewed was not initiated within 7 calendar
days after receipt of the information. The investigation referral occurred on
12/04/2017, whereas the foster parents were not informed of the investigation until
an unannounced visit occurred on 12/29/2017.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 10/24/2017 SIR#2017C0217006
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
One out of three special evaluations reviewed did not contain evidence of the report
being given the social service worker of the child placed in the foster home.
R400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
5

One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain evidence of a physical
examination as occurring. A 12/22/17 Well Exam is noted in MiSACWIS though no
documentation was uploaded.
One foster care case record identified by the analyst as having issues with the
transfer of medical records determined the annual updated physical as pending.
R400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least
every 18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed was late in obtaining an
updated dental examination. The last dental examination on file was dated
01/16/2017, and is currently three months late.
R400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to
the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical
care.
6

Three out of eight applicable foster care case records reviewed did not contain
evidence of the replacement packet acknowledgement being signed by the foster
parents.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One out of eight applicable foster care case records reviewed contained a late initial
service plan by 49 days. It is noted that the agency did not have access to the case
record in MiSACWIS in order to complete the service plan timely.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Three out of eight foster care case records reviewed contained late updated service
plans. Two separate case records service plans were late by one and seven days,
whereas the third case records service plans were late by five and ten days.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
One out of four independent living records reviewed did not document the rationale
for selection of independent living as the most appropriate placement for the youth. It
is noted that the youth’s Initial Youth Assessment was not entirely completed.
R 400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health
care provided shall be documented in the youth's record.
7

One out of four independent living records reviewed was late in completing an
updated physical examination. The previous physical examination was completed
on 04/17/2017, whereas the current physical examination was completed on
07/03/2018, three weeks late.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth’s
biological children or a clear explanation why this is not
possible or appropriate. (3) youth's record.
Two out of four independent living records reviewed contained late updated service
plans by three days in one case record, whereas the second case record contained
two late USP’s by three and nine days.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.18 Page Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
23 54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative
foster parents within 180 days of the date of placement.
The agency has one relative placement that has not been licensed within 180 days
of the date of placement. The agency received the referral on 02/23/2018 and are
awaiting FIG funding for a basement bedroom. The relatives are also noted as
being difficult to contact and returns messages.
ISEP 6.33(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
Page 28
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
8

available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain a birth parent signature
on their service plan. It is noted that only one out of three service plans from the
case record did not contain a signature.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 10/11/2017 RENEWAL INSPECTION
ISEP 6.49 – Med passports
Page 34
The medical passport shall be updated quarterly.
Five out of eight foster care case records were deficient quarterly updated medical
passports. One case record was deficient one quarter, three case records were
deficient two quarters each, and one case record was deficient three quarters.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Family Team Meeting
722-06B page 1
The Family Team Meeting (FTM) is due within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Three out of eight foster care case records reviewed were deficient a FTM within the
case plan period. Two were deficient one FTM, whereas the third was deficient two
FTM’s.
DHHS Policy Unannounced Home Visit – Caseworker Contact with
FOM 722-6H – Caregivers.
Page 7 and 5
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the home
every quarter. The unannounced visit must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
The first face-to-face contact with the child must take place
within five business days from the date the case is assigned to
9

the caseworker or within five business days of the date of the
placement move.
Seven out of eight foster care case records reviewed did not contain quarterly
unannounced home visits to the foster home. Six case records were deficient one
unannounced visit each, whereas one case record was deficient two unannounced
visits.
One out of nine foster care case records reviewed did not contain a face-to-face
contact within five business days from the date the case was assigned.
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s).
FOM 722-06H
Page 10
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
Three out of eight applicable foster care case records reviewed did not contain
quarterly home visits to the birth parent’s residence. Two case records were
deficient one home visit each, whereas one case record was deficient two home
visits.
DHHS Policy Supervisory Approval - ISP
FOM 722-08
Page 23
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of the
Report Date.
Two out of three applicable foster care case records reviewed contained late
supervisor signatures to initial service plans by 11 and 25 days. It is noted that one
of the late supervisor signatures was the result of the agency not having access to
the case record in MiSACWIS.
DHHS Policy Supervisory Approval - USP
FOM 722-09
Page 27
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
10

Four out of eight applicable foster care case records reviewed contain late
supervisor signatures to updated service plans. Three case records were late one
service plan each by 02, 04, and 21 days, whereas the third case record was late
two service plans by 32 and 34 days.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver
Page 2
The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates
that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Four out of eight foster care records reviewed were deficient foster parent signatures
on treatment plans. Two case records each were deficient foster parent signatures
for one treatment plan each, whereas the two other case records were deficient
foster parent signatures one three treatment plans each.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 10/11/2017 RENEWAL INSPECTION
FOM 722-03 Placement Change
Page 18
DHHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
required for placement changes.
Two out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed were deficient the DHHS-69
when the foster child was replaced on 05/10/2018 and 07/03/2018.
DHHS Policy Permanency Plan Approval Packet APPLA
FOM 722-07F –
page 8-9
Was a DHHS-569 [Permanency Goal Support Agreement],
Permanency Pact, and DHHS-347 [Permanency Goal Approval]
completed and submitted to the PRM [Permanency Resource
Monitor] for review.
11

Four out of four independent living records reviewed did not contain verification of
the APPLA packet being uploaded into MiSACWIS. It is noted that such
documentation should have been completed prior to placement in independent living
and by the referring agency.
DHHS IL+ ILP Program Requirements-Client Eligibility Criteria
Contract Oct 17:
1.1.b. Page 2
Continuing eligibility Criteria-Ansell-Casey Life Skills
Assessment: Every 90 days, the youth shall be evaluated using
the applicable Casey Life Skills Assessment (CLSA) to
determine continued eligibility/suitability for placement. If the
youth lacks sufficient progress to transition into general IL, they
will be considered eligible to remain in the ILP program.
Two out of four independent living records reviewed were deficient with updated
Ansell-Casey Life Skills Assessments for one quarter each.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a youth
is placed in independent living:
(c) That the youth’s social service worker has personally
observed and determined that the living situation is safe
and that the youth has a bed and has access to cooking
and bathing facilities.
(e) An evaluation of a youth's need for supervision and a
plan for providing the level of supervision determined
necessary.
The agency utilizes its own placement setting within the independent living plus
program. It is recommended that the agency document in the case record, before
placement, that the case manager has personally observed and determined that the
living situation is safe due to changing placement conditions.
The agency’s independent living plus program requires four contacts per month. It is
recommended that the intake assessment specifically document the youth’s need for
supervision as a youth’s evaluated need for supervision could be assessed as more
than four days per month.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
12

(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed.
The plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(i) Specify the methods, the persons responsible,
the time frames for correction; methods for
ensuring the safety of any children placed in the
home; how continuing compliance will be
maintained once compliance is achieved;
consequences if the corrective action plan is not
completed; and what documentation will be
required to demonstrate compliance or
completion.
One corrective action plan reviewed indicated the foster parent needed to complete
the required number of training hours. It is recommended that the agency indicate
the specific amount of training hours needed within corrective action plans.
DHHS Policy CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
FOM 722-6H PLACEMENT
Page 5
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement Move
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with the child for the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face
contact with the child must take place within five business days
from the date the case is assigned to the caseworker or within
five business days of the date of the placement move. At least
one contact each month must take place at the child’s
placement location.
A prior agency completed a USP of a child transferred to the agency within 30 days.
The prior agency did not document the first visit from the ongoing agency as the
ongoing agency did not have access to the case record in MiSACWIS. A
06/25/2018 progress note states the ongoing agency having completed a second
visit. It is recommended that the ongoing agency assure that prior agency’s
completing USP’s within the first 30 days of transfers include all contacts made by
the ongoing agency.
13

R 400.12404 Placement.
An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
4400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(f) The child’s legal status and agency’s legal right to provide
care.
The agency made a relative placement in western Michigan. The agency then
referred the relative to another, separately licensed, regional office of Samaritas for
licensure. The agency maintained court responsibility while the other regional office
of Samaritas provided case management services due to proximity. The court
ordered the other regional office to maintain court responsibility as of 07/27/2018
and the case was transferred. The agency that receives a DHHS 3600 is
responsible for services provided as that agency has the legal right to provide care.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the renewal inspection report
dated 10/11/2017. It appropriately addressed the following as no repeat citations
are noted: Foster parent 60-day recent of application, foster parent training hours,
prior approval for borrowed bed, timely ISP, monthly foster home visits, IL location
documentation at termination, medical passport signatures and uploading into
MiSACWIS, and uploading IL assessment into MiSACWIS. Repeat citations include
birth and foster parent signatures on treatment plans and updated first aid training
for foster parents.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for SIR#2017C0217006 initiated on
10/24/2017. It addressed the opening of a special evaluation rather than completing
an addendum when allegations are like one’s previously investigated. It is noted
that the current citation within this interim inspection pertains to the initiation of the
special evaluation within seven days, rather than just opening a special evaluation.
14

The agency submitted a corrective action plan for SIR#2019C0219001 initiated on
10/04/2018. It appropriately addressed placement of foster children in home IL
provider’s homes without being appropriately assessed for IL as no repeat citations
are noted.
The 07/09/2018 analyst report was reviewed and follow up to concerns are as
follows:
Safety and Concern Alert #1:
Safety issue: The Analyst observed that the basement was being used as living
space with no window that family members could use as an
emergency exit. The foster parents reported that the original
licensing worker who did their home study did not inform them that
they were out of compliance. They said their license became active
04/05/2018. They said they became aware of the non-compliance
when a second licensing worker visited their home during the first
week of 06/2018.
Resolution: The foster parents were made aware of the
requirements for basements during orientation. Licensing worker’s
03/26/2018 email to foster parent, prior to licensure, states
basement cannot be used. Foster parents have furniture in
basement that cannot be relocated. Foster parents reminded of
requirements regarding basement living spaces and signed a
basement usage agreement.
Concern: The foster parents say that the agency did not provide information
about a discontinuance of the child’s psychiatric medication. They
say that when they went to pick the child up, institution that
released the child did not release this information, either. The
foster parents reported that the child had been taking Zoloft for a
long period of time. The foster parents said that without the
medication, there were behavior changes that made the child a
danger to herself, other people, and animals in the foster home.
Resolution: The residential facility where the foster child was
placed prior the foster home discontinued the foster child’s Zoloft.
DCWL does not regulate the clinical directives of physicians.
Concern: The foster parents reported that the foster care worker refused to
provide a referral to a psychiatrist, so they could have the child
evaluated and receive assistance with managing her behavior
changes.
Resolution: The agency had the case nine days before the foster
child was removed and placed in a residential facility. The child
15

previously had a psychiatric evaluation and was discontinued
medication. It is noted that the foster child refused to stay in the
pre-adoptive home.
Concern: The foster parents also reported that the caseworker who was
assigned at the time did not visit the child for 7 days after she was
placed in the home.
Resolution: Case record review confirms that a face-to-face
contact with between the foster child and case manager did not
occur within five days of placement. The agency was cited as non-
compliant.
Safety and Concern Alert #2:
Safety issue: One child is sleeping on a mattress on the floor. He needs a
bedframe.
Resolution: The agency received the alert on 06/15/2018 with a
due date for completion of 06/22/2018 in which a bedframe was to
be obtained. The foster parent requested that the foster children be
removed as the landlord asked her to move and foster parent
consequently moving into senior housing. The foster children were
removed from the home on 06/22/2018.
Concern: Relative stated that she was not provided with information on
financial assistance or resources.
Resolution: Relative was instructed to contact DHHS to apply for
cash assistance and food stamps for support.
Safety and Concern Alert #3:
Safety issue: The home has a pond in the backyard. There are bells on the door
as an alert, but the home does not have rescue items such as a
flotation ring or shepherd hook in case of emergency.
Resolution: The foster home was not licensed by the agency, but
rather licensed through another regional office of the Samaritas
organization. The licensing agency was made aware of the
deficient rescue item on 07/09/2018 and was delivered to the home
on 07/11/2018 with the confirmation picture being sent by the foster
parent on 07/13/2018. The agency was reminded that urgent
safety alerts need to be addressed immediately regardless of the
responsible licensing agency
16

Concern: There are ongoing issues with the transfer of medical records,
which has resulted in a delay of medical and mental health services
for the child.
Resolution: Case record review indicates foster child receiving
therapy from time of placement through 12/2017 when her therapist
went into private practice and at which time foster child followed her
therapist. Foster child transferred back to her original CMH in
09/2018 where she has continued therapy. Foster child’s last
physical examination occurred on 08/22/2017 and the annual
updated examination is pending. The agency was cited as non-
compliant. It is noted that the agency was not servicing the foster
care case, rather it was being serviced through another, separately
licensed, regional office of the Samaritas organization. The agency
was provided technical assistance on placement.
Concern: The relative said she does not have the child’s medical insurance
card.
Resolution: Case record review indicates the relative receiving the
child’s medical insurance card at time of her placement on
08/03/32016. It is noted that the agency was not servicing the
foster care case, rather it was being serviced through another,
separately licensed, regional office of the Samaritas organization.
The agency was provided technical assistance on placement.
Concern: The relative reported that the caseworker does not maintain contact
with her.
Resolution: Case record review indicates regular contacts between
the case manager and relative being made. Contacts are noted as
occurring on the following dates: 01/24, 02/26, 03/14, 04/06, 04/09,
04/19, 04/23, 05/10, 06/01, 06/21/07/19, 08/06, 08/09, and
09/21/2018. It is noted that the agency was not servicing the foster
care case, rather it was being serviced through another, separately
licensed, regional office of the Samaritas organization. The agency
was provided technical assistance on placement.
Safety and Concern Alert #4:
Concern: No unannounced visits have occurred during the time
that the
children have been placed.
17

Resolution: Case record review indicates an unannounced visit
occurred on 11/13/2017 in MiSACWIS. Additional unannounced
visits are noted as occurring, via the supervisor tracking form, on
01/02/2018, 02/20/2018, and 04/17/2018. It is noted that the
worker entered home visits as parenting time in MiSACWIS.
Correct data entry was addressed during regular supervision.
Concern: Birth Father
• He does not know what his service plan is.
• He did not give input into a service plan.
• He did not sign a service plan
• He was not given notification of FTMs.
• He has not attended FTM’s, as he did not know about them.
• He is not involved in the decisions regarding his child’s
education.
• He is not involved in the decisions regarding his child’s
medical needs.
• He is not involved in the decisions regarding his child’s
physical appearance
• He was not given notification his child’s medical
appointments, school meetings, or emergencies.
• His caseworker is not in contact with him.
